message_1: Suppose the heights of students in a class are normally distributed with a mean of 65 inches and a standard deviation of 3 inches. What percentage of the class has a height between 62 inches and 68 inches?
message_2:
To find the percentage of students with a height between 62 inches and 68 inches, we will use the z-score formula and the standard normal distribution table.

The z-score formula is:

z = (X - μ) / σ

where X is the data point, μ is the mean, and σ is the standard deviation.

First, we will find the z-scores for 62 inches and 68 inches.

For 62 inches:
z1 = (62 - 65) / 3
z1 = -3 / 3
z1 = -1

For 68 inches:
z2 = (68 - 65) / 3
z2 = 3 / 3
z2 = 1

Now, we will look up the z-scores in the standard normal distribution table to find the corresponding probabilities.

For z1 = -1, the probability is 0.1587 (15.87%).
For z2 = 1, the probability is 0.8413 (84.13%).

To find the percentage of students with a height between 62 inches and 68 inches, we will subtract the probability of z1 from the probability of z2.

Percentage = P(z2) - P(z1)
Percentage = 0.8413 - 0.1587
Percentage = 0.6826

So, approximately 68.26% of the class has a height between 62 inches and 68 inches.
